title: Lord Fraser takes on Extinction Rebellion in just a dressing gown
text:
Lord Andrew Fraser confronts protesters outside his door (Picture: eyevine)

A Conservative peer confronted drumming Extinction Rebellion protesters this morning wearing just a dressing gown and his slippers.

Lord Andrew Fraser, 72, began gesticulating in front of the environmental activists, at one point holding his fists up, as they marched down his street in Westminster.

The former Tory party treasurer said he had ‘had enough’ of the demonstrators, who began drumming near to the Houses of Parliament at around 9.15 am.

As the old saying goes, if you can’t beat ’em, join ’em, which is what Lord Fraser did, without even stopping to get dressed.

He approached one woman and started banging her own drum with his fists.

He said he found the activists ‘intimidating’ (Picture: eyevine)

He held up his fists as the protesters made their way down his street (Picture: eyevine)

The Tory peer told one bystander ‘I enjoyed that’ after banging an XR drum (Picture: eyevine)

The former investment banker later told the Evening Standard: ‘I’d had enough of the noise and disruption. It’s intimidating.

‘I liken it to the marching bands in Northern Ireland.’

He added: ‘We have had sleepless nights and traffic has been blocked. Sometimes you need to drive somewhere.

‘I banged the drum, there was no physical contact with the woman.’

He reportedly told a bystander after the confrontation: ‘I enjoyed that.’

The XR activists attempted to hand the Lord a leaflet as they passed through his street with wheelbarrows of fruit and vegetables.

Protesters set up camp in Smithfield Meat Market last night and today forced out traders by taking over their stalls and only selling plant products.

Some shouted ‘beef equals grief’ as the stall holders arrived to find the tent village.
